org.obrel.core

Interface Relatable

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    FluentRelatable<T>, ObjectSpace<T>, RelatableMixin, RelationBuilder<R>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractAction, AbstractBinaryFunction, AbstractBinaryPredicate, AbstractFunction, AbstractInvertibleFunction, AbstractPredicate, AutomaticType, BinaryFunctionChain, BinaryFunctionChain.LeftFunctionChain, BinaryFunctionChain.RightFunctionChain, BinaryFunctionGroup, BinaryPredicateChain, Cast, ClassPredicate, ClassPredicate.HasBaseClass, ClassPredicate.HasClass, CollectorType, Comparison, Comparison.ElementOf, Comparison.EqualTo, Comparison.GreaterOrEqual, Comparison.GreaterThan, Comparison.LessOrEqual, Comparison.LessThan, Comparison.Matching, Comparison.SameAs, ConditionalFunction, ConstraintType, Conversions.DateToStringConversion, Conversions.StringConversion, CountElements, CounterType, CreateHash, DirectRelation, DualFunctionChain, ElementPredicate, ExceptionMappingAction, ExceptionMappingBinaryFunction, ExceptionMappingBinaryPredicate, ExceptionMappingFunction, ExceptionMappingPredicate, ExtractString, FileSystemSpace, FunctionChain, FunctionPredicate, GetElement, GetElement.GetField, GetElement.GetListElement, GetElement.GetMapValue, GetElement.GetRelation, GetElement.GetRelationValue, GetElement.ReadField, GetSubstring, Group, HtmlSpace, IntermediateRelation, Invert, InvokeMethod, JsonObject, JsonRelatedObject, ListenerType, ListType, MappedSpace, MapType, Params, PredicateChain, PredicateJoin, Predicates.And, Predicates.Not, Predicates.Or, Print, RelatedObject, Relation, RelationAlias, RelationSpace, RelationTokenFormat, RelationType, RelationTypeFilter, RelationView, RelationWrapper, SerializableRelatedObject, SetElement, SetElement.SetListElement, SetElement.SetMapValue, SetElement.SetRelationValue, SetType, SynchronizedObjectSpace, TimerType, TokenStringFormat, TransformedRelation

    public interface Relatable
    This interface defines the public methods that are provided by related objects. It's main purpose is to be used as a base interface for other interfaces, so that implementations of such interfaces can be used as related objects without casting to RelatedObject. But implementations cannot implement the methods of this interface by themselves. Instead, they must inherit the implementation by extending the base class RelatedObject because this base class contains additional management methods.

    If subclassing RelatedObject is not possible this interface must not be used. The handling of object relations should then be done through the corresponding methods of the ObjectRelations class which can be applied to arbitrary objects.

    Application code that needs to check for relation handling capability of objects with the instanceof operator should do so by checking against this interface (and not RelatedObject). That will make the code compatible with possible future extensions which could provide other implementations of this interface.

    All methods in this interface that expect a predicate parameter will only work on public relations, i.e. relations with a type that doesn't have the relation type modifier RelationTypeModifier.PRIVATE set.

    • Method Detail

      • deleteRelation

        default void deleteRelation(RelationType<?> rType)
        Deletes a particular relation from this object. This will also cause all alias relations that have been created for this relation to be deleted. The alias removal is unconditional (i.e. it cannot be prevented by the alias relation type) because aliases won't work without the original relation.
        Parameters:
        rType - The type of the relation to delete
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If the relation type has the flag RelationTypeModifier.FINAL set

      • deleteRelation

        void deleteRelation(Relation<?> rRelation)
        Deletes a certain relation from this instance.
        Parameters:
        rRelation - The relation to be removed from this instance

      • deleteRelations

        default void deleteRelations(Predicate<? super Relation<?>> rFilter)
        Deletes all public relations from this instance that match a certain filter. See the method deleteRelation(RelationType) for more details.
        Parameters:
        rFilter - The relation filter or NULL for all relations

      • get

        <T> T get(RelationType<T> rType)
        Returns the resolved value of the relation that matches a certain relation type. If that relation does not exist already but the type implements the method RelationType.initialValue(Relatable) which returns a value that is not NULL a new relation with that target value will be created and it's resolved value returned. Otherwise the result of RelationType.defaultValue(Relatable) will be returned (which is NULL by default).

        The initial and default value mechanisms imply that this method cannot be used to check the existence of relations in an object. If a type provides an initial value relations will be created automatically when queried through this method. If it returns a default value the relation doesn't exist at all although a value is available. Therefore, to check for relations the method hasRelation(RelationType) must be invoked instead. This will also avoid the automatic creation of the relations that are queried. In addition, other relation query methods like getAll(Predicate) and getRelation(RelationType) will ignore initial and default values.

        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type to return the target of
        Returns:
        The resolved target object or NULL if no relation with the given type exists

      • get

        default <T> T get(RelationType<T> rType,
                  T rDefaultValue)
        Returns a value if a relation with the given type exists or else returns a default value. If a relation exists and has a NULL value the returned value will be NULL.
        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type to check
        rDefaultValue - The default value to return if no relation exists
        Returns:
        Either the relation value or the default value

      • get

        default int get(RelationType<java.lang.Integer> rType,
                int nDefaultValue)
        Returns an integer value if a relation with the given type exists or else returns a default value. Attention: if a relation exists and has a NULL value a NullPointerException will occur!
        Parameters:
        rType - The integer relation type to check
        nDefaultValue - The default value to return if no relation exists
        Returns:
        Either the relation value or the default value

      • getAll

        default java.util.List<java.lang.Object> getAll(Predicate<? super Relation<?>> rFilter)
        Returns a list of all resolved target objects of an object's public relations that match a certain filter. The order in which the relations appear in the collection will be the same on multiple invocations of this method. The returned list can be freely modified by the caller.
        Parameters:
        rFilter - The relation filter or NULL for all relation values
        Returns:
        A list containing the resolved targets of all matching relations (may be empty but will never be NULL)

        <T> Relation<T> getRelation(RelationType<T> rType)
        Returns a certain relation of this instance.
        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type to return the relation of
        Returns:
        The corresponding relation or NULL if no such relation exists

      • getRelations

        java.util.List<Relation<?>> getRelations(Predicate<? super Relation<?>> rFilter)
        Returns a list of all public relations that match a certain filter. The order in which the relations appear in the collection will be the same on multiple invocations of this method. The returned list can be freely modified by the caller.
        Parameters:
        rFilter - The relation filter or NULL for all relations
        Returns:
        A list containing the matching relations (may be empty but will never be NULL)

      • hasFlag

        default boolean hasFlag(RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> rType)
        A convenience method that checks the state of a relation with a type that resolves to a boolean value. Other than get(RelationType) this method doesn't perform an automatic initialization of relations with the given type.
        Parameters:
        rType - A relation type that resolves to a boolean value
        Returns:
        TRUE if this instance has a relation for the given type which is set to TRUE; FALSE if no relation exists of if it's value is FALSE

      • hasRelation

        default boolean hasRelation(RelationType<?> rType)
        A shortcut method that checks whether this instance contains a relation with the given relation type. This call is equivalent to (rObj.getRelationCount(rType) > 0).
        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type to check the
        Returns:
        TRUE if this instance has a relation for the given type

      • hasRelations

        default boolean hasRelations(Predicate<? super Relation<?>> rFilter)
        A shortcut method that checks whether this instance contains at least one public relation that matches a certain filter. This call is equivalent to (rObj.getRelationCount(rFilter) > 0).
        Parameters:
        rFilter - The relation filter to search matching relations for
        Returns:
        TRUE if this instance has at least one public relation that matches the given filter

      • init

        default <T> Relation<T> init(RelationType<T> rType)
        Initializes a relation with a certain type so that the relation exists afterwards. First tries to create the initial value of the relation type with get(RelationType). If that yields NULL indicating that no initial value exists and therefore no relation has been created it invokes set(RelationType, Object) with a NULL value to create a new creation. the given relation type to set it's initial value.
        Parameters:
        rType - The type of the relation to initialize
        Returns:
        The relation for the given type

      • set

        default Relation<java.lang.Boolean> set(RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> rFlagType)
        A convenience method that sets a relation with a type that has a boolean target value to TRUE. This is often used for flag relation types and a shortcut for invoking set(RelationType, Object) with a target value of TRUE.
        Parameters:
        rFlagType - A relation type with a boolean target
        Returns:
        Returns the relation that has been modified or created

      • set

        default void set(RelationData<?>... rRelations)
        Sets multiple relations at once by applying them from instances of the class RelationData. If used with a static import of the factory method RelationData.r(RelationType, Object) it allows a compact assignment of multiple relations at once.
        Parameters:
        rRelations - rRelationDatas The relation data objects to set the relations from

      • set

        <T> Relation<T> set(RelationType<T> rType,
                    T rTarget)
        Sets a relation to the given target object with a certain relation type to this instance. If this is the first call for the given type a new relation with that type will be created.
        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type
        rTarget - The unresolved target object of the relation
        Returns:
        Returns the relation that has been modified or created
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given type is not applicable for the object

      • set

        default Relation<java.lang.Integer> set(RelationType<java.lang.Integer> rIntType,
                                        int nValue)
        A convenience method to set integer relations from an int value without an auto-boxing warning.
        Parameters:
        rIntType - The integer relation type
        nValue - The int value to set
        Returns:
        The relation that has been created or updated

      • set

        <T,I> Relation<T> set(RelationType<T> rType,
                      Function<I,T> fTargetResolver,
                      I rIntermediateTarget)
        Creates a relation that initially stores the target value in an intermediate format. When the relation target is queried it will be created by applying a conversion function to the intermediate value. This allows to lazily initialize relations only when they are really needed.

        If a relation with the given type exists already this method will throw an exception to prevent the inadvertent overriding of relations. If the caller explicitly wants to replace an existing relation it must delete the previous relation before invoking this method.

        The serialized format of an intermediate relation depends on the intermediate target value and the conversion function. If both are serializable they will be serialized directly. If one of them is not serializable the intermediate target value will be converted to the final target format before which will then be serialized.

        This method is intended to be used by frameworks that need to prevent the early resolving of relations. A possible application would be a persistence framework that wants to perform lazy loading of child objects.

        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type
        fTargetResolver - The function that must be applied to the intermediate target value to resolve the final target value
        rIntermediateTarget - The intermediate target value (must not be NULL)
        Returns:
        The new intermediate relation
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If a relation with the given type exists already

      • streamRelations

        default java.util.stream.Stream<Relation<?>> streamRelations()
        Returns a stream of all relations in this object.
        Returns:
        The stream of relations

      • transform

        <T,D> TransformedRelation<T,D> transform(RelationType<T> rType,
                                         InvertibleFunction<T,D> fTransformation)
        Creates a relation that stores the target value in a transformed format. If a new target value is set it will be converted to the transformed format by applying a transformation function. If the target is queried from the relation it will be created from the transformed value by inverting the transformation. Therefore the function argument must implement the InvertibleFunction interface.

        If a relation with the given type exists already it will be replaced with the transformed relation and it's current target value will be transformed automatically. If no such relation exists the transformation will be created with the initial value of the relation type.

        If a transformed relation shall be serializable both it's transformed target value and the transformation function must be serializable too. Otherwise an exception will occur when an attempt is made to serialize the relation.

        This method is intended to be used by frameworks that want to provide a way to store relations in a specific format. A possible application would be a framework that encrypts relations.

        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type
        fTransformation - The transformation to apply to target values
        Returns:
        The new transformed relation
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If the relation to be transformed is an alias or view
